objections.text: The section assumes a seamless transition from mathematical notation to computational language without addressing potential challenges or differences. Acknowledging and discussing the differences between the evolution of mathematical notation and the adoption of computational language would provide a more nuanced understanding of the shift.

The term 'superpower' used to describe the Wolfram Language lacks a clear and specific definition. Providing a more concrete explanation of what constitutes the 'superpower' and how it distinguishes the Wolfram Language from other languages would enhance the audience's understanding.

The section states that AIs leverage computational language as a tool to integrate technology into LLMs to compute new facts. However, this claim lacks specific examples or evidence to support the assertion. Providing concrete instances or studies demonstrating the successful integration of computational language into AI systems would strengthen this argument.

While discussing societal dilemmas arising from computational irreducibility, the section does not present counterarguments or alternative perspectives. Considering and addressing potential counterarguments related to societal dilemmas would contribute to a more comprehensive and balanced exploration of the topic.

objections.capture: Assumption of AI Direction through Human Desires
objections.text: The section assumes that directing AI lies in defining human desires without critically examining potential ethical concerns or biases associated with this approach. Acknowledging and addressing the ethical implications and potential challenges related to defining human desires for AI would enhance the depth of the discussion.

objections.capture: Generalization of AI Outcomes as 'Random and Pointless'
objections.text: The description of AI outcomes as potentially 'random and pointless' lacks clarity and could be seen as an oversimplification. Providing more nuanced insights into the potential outcomes of AI exploration and the factors that contribute to their perceived value or purpose would offer a more balanced perspective.

objections.capture: Assumption of Seamless Integration of Computational Language
objections.text: The section assumes a seamless integration of computational language as the tool to chart paths and define goals without discussing potential challenges or limitations. Addressing potential hurdles or criticisms related to the integration of computational language into human-centered processes would provide a more thorough exploration of the topic.

objections.capture: Lack of Critical Examination of 'Computational Superpowers'
objections.text: The term 'computational superpowers' is introduced without a critical examination of its implications or potential limitations. Discussing potential criticisms or concerns related to the concept of 'computational superpowers' would contribute to a more balanced and thorough analysis.

capture: Психоанализ риторики Другого в творчестве Ж.-П. Сартра: Холокост, Вторая мировая война и европейское общество в оккупации. Виктория Суковатая
description: Вторая мировая война и Холокост  стали важнейшими источниками формирование «дискурса  вины» в европейской  культуре второй половины ХХ века. В 1950-1970-е годы в западном искусстве все чаще появляются произведения, в которых война, не присутствуя фактически, тем не менее, воспроизводилась в ситуациях нравственного  выбора, в мотивах беспомощности или безысходности, как, например, в фильмах И. Бергмана «Причастие» и «Седьмая печать», и многих других. Дискурсы «сопротивления» и «вины» стали  центральными в послевоенных дискуссиях в период формирования контркультуры (1970-е годы). Не стал исключением французский интеллектуал Сартр: по мнению биографов [13], война и необходимость правильного выбора человека в «экзистенциальной ситуации» стали узловой темой в творчестве Сартра. «Случай Сартра» можно  представить как  «универсальную биографию» западного человека ХХ века – человека христианской культуры, воспитанного многолетними  говорениями о свободе,  осознающего себя как носителя моральных ценностей, и при этом столкнувшегося с жестокостью  Холокоста и личной и общественной неспособностью противостоять ему;  человека, подавленного  пониманием ответственности за то, что цивилизационные проекты  под названием «западная демократия» и «христианская культура» оказались неспособны предотвратить геноцид миллионов   других, оказавшихся   в оккупации и плену.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of Social Science Department

summary.text: Жан-Поль Сартр – лидер европейской философии ХХ века, основатель экзистенциализма. Концепция Другого, введенная им в 'Бытии и Ничто', занимает центральное место в современной философии. Сам Сартр, принадлежа к высшему слою интеллигенции, проявлял интерес к расовому, классовому и сексуальному 'Другому', поддерживая радикальных эмигрантов и африканскую интеллигенцию.

В период студенческих волнений 1968-1970 годов, Сартр поддерживал революционные акции против 'общества потребления'. Его арест в 1970 году за продажу маоистских листовок свидетельствует о его активном участии в протестах. Сартр также выступал за постмодернистскую концепцию 'гомосексуалиста как культурного Другого', поддерживая Жана Жене и превращая его в символ свободы.

Сартр оказал огромное влияние на формирование теории Другого. Его работы содержат 'зародыши' современных дискурсов о черном, постколониальном, гендерном и сексуальном Другом. Биография Сартра становится универсальным образом западноевропейского интеллектуала середины ХХ века.

Что побудило Сартра проявлять глубокий интерес к формам идентичности, долгое время отчуждавшимся европейским субъектом? Возможно, решающим стало его психобиографическое и экзистенциальное переживание в годы Второй мировой войны. В исследовании предлагается новая интерпретация концепции Другого в свете личного опыта Сартра.

Вторая мировая война стала рубежным событием, перекраившим тело Европы и сознание наций. Европейское общество ХХ века ожидало поступательного развития, но войны, Холокост, ГУЛАГ и нацистская утопия привели к трагедии. Технический прогресс и образование не привнесли предвиденного расцвета культуры и человеколюбия.

Две мировые войны, Аушвиц, Холокост, ГУЛАГ и более 30 миллионов жертв стали символами ХХ века. Вторая мировая война привела к тому, что 65% погибших составляло мирное население, получившее 'травму войны'. Это изменило моральные ценности, подорвало 'культурный оптимизм' и вызвало сомнения в либеральных ценностях и универсальной 'истине'.

Для французских интеллигентов, воспитанных идеалами прав человека и философиями Гоббса, Вольтера, Гегеля, Вторая мировая война стала критическим рубежом. Жившие войну интеллектуалы сталкивались с вопросами справедливости, роли христианства и своей ответственности за происходящее. Холокост и война подорвали веру в превосходство христианской культуры, вызвав постоянную рефлексию.

Сартр, лидер европейской философии, выжил в войне, проведя девять месяцев в немецких лагерях. После войны для западноевропейских интеллектуалов стало невозможным говорить о превосходстве христианской культуры. Война стала точкой 'рождения травмы' западного человека, определяя интеллектуальную и общественную активность Сартра.

Франция в период оккупации была разделена на север и юг, под контролем Германии и Виши соответственно. Несмотря на видимость независимости на юге, тысячи беженцев, включая французов, патриотов и евреев, уходили от нацистов. Французские евреи до Второй мировой войны активно поддерживали культу французской нации, но оккупация и Законы о евреях Виши разрушили их надежды и идентичность.

Французские евреи, вплоть до Второй мировой, соединяли французский патриотизм с уважением к своим культурным традициям. Но война и оккупация перевернули ситуацию. В первые месяцы оккупации, под давлением Германии, правительство Виши приняло Законы о евреях, нарушившие принципы Французской республики.

Французское общество в период оккупации столкнулось с драмой беженцев, включая историю журнала 'Анналы'. Под давлением нацистов совладельцу журнала, еврею Марку Блоку, предложили продолжить издание, но под контролем Германии. Блок отказался, несмотря на свою преданность Франции и уважение, заработанное в Первую мировую войну.

Евреи играли ключевую роль в обсуждении статуса в оккупированной Европе. Нацисты считали западных европейцев близкими расово и стремились привлечь их к сотрудничеству. Однако европейские евреи, ставшие первыми жертвами нацистского геноцида, оказались 'уязвимыми'.

Марк Блок, ставший участником Сопротивления во Вторую мировую войну, ушел в подполье, проявив себя хорошим офицером из Первой мировой войны. Его группа антифашистов совершала боевые акции, попала в руки нацистов, и Блок был расстрелян вместе с товарищами, но не как еврей, а как французский патриот.

Во французском Сопротивлении участвовали люди разных национальностей, включая евреев, бежавших из Польши и концлагерей, а также югославов, итальянцев, испанцев, англичан, русских эмигрантов и советских офицеров. Советские военнопленные и польские евреи составляли отчаянные боевые группы, осуществлявшие смелые операции против нацистов.

summary.capture: Особенности восприятия евреев и советских военнопленных
summary.text: В нацистской иерархии жертв советские военнопленные и польские евреи занимали наиболее уязвимую позицию. Отношение к советским военным было особенно жестоким, они подвергались геноциду, рассматривались как 'русские' и ассоциировались с 'большевиками'. Они стали жертвами отравляющих газов и подвергались систематическому уничтожению, в то время как французы, британцы и другие военнопленные имели более мягкую участь.

summary.capture: Влияние Хайдеггера и возвращение в Париж
summary.text: Находясь в лагере для французских военнопленных, Сартр написал свою первую рождественскую пьесу и изучил 'Бытие и Время' М. Хайдеггера, чья методология оказала влияние на Сартра. Из-за пошатнувшегося здоровья в апреле 1941 года Сартр был выпущен из лагеря немецкими властями и вернулся в Париж.

summary.capture: Противоречия в Париже и участие в Сопротивлении
summary.text: Сартр получил должность преподавателя, но ощущал угнетенность и чувство вины, занимая место, освободившееся после увольнения профессора-еврея. Возможно, это внутреннее 'примирение' с антисемитской кампанией нацистов послужило причиной его пост-военного протеста против антисемитизма, расизма и гомофобии.

Колледж, где работал Сартр, был закрыт, и он присоединился к группе Сопротивления. Французское Сопротивление было разнообразным, как по составу, так и идеологически. Недостаток финансов и разногласия с коммунистами привели к распаду группы. В это время Сартр писал трактат 'Бытие и ничто', посвятив значительную часть проблеме существования Другого.

Сартр анализирует концепцию Другого, начиная с того, что определяет своего субъекта. В 'Бытии и ничто' он подчеркивает телесность философии, связывая ее с войной и сопротивлением. Он описывает повседневность субъекта, мучаемого неврозами, страхами и фобиями, особенно в контексте оккупированного Парижа.

Сартр пережил войну и оккупацию, но тема войны преследовала его до конца жизни. В 1946 году он написал антифашистскую пьесу 'Мертвые без погребения', а в 1949 году опубликовал 'Размышления о еврейском вопросе', рассматриваемые как первые попытки осмыслить источники культурного антисемитизма в послевоенной философии.

Сартр обращается к методу из 'Бытия и ничто', утверждая, что еврей является Другим, воспринимаемым другими как Другой. Однако он указывает на логическую ловушку, где любой, отличающийся от субъекта, может быть считаться евреем. Проблема еврейства теряет 'национально-расовую', телесную природу и превращается в семиотический аспект, связанный с 'исключением' и 'отчуждением'.

Послевоенная деятельность Сартра характеризовалась как 'протестная' и могла быть компенсацией за чувство вины, возникшее в период нацистской оккупации. Сартр вложил всю себя в послевоенное время, подвергая себя опасностям в поиске более активного участия, которого он не рискнул во времена войны.

summary.capture: Критика относительно действий во время войны
summary.text: Сергей Фокин, в статье 'Экзистенциализм – это коллаборационизм?', выделяет неактивность французских экзистенциалистов, включая Сартра, в борьбе с фашизмом во время оккупации. Это вызывало пренебрежение от тех, кто рисковал жизнью в те годы, и Сартр стал активным послевоенным ангажированным с целью компенсации и переоценки собственных действий в прошлом.

summary.capture: Послевоенная активность и участие в протестах
summary.text: Сартр после войны принимал участие в публичных акциях протеста, вступал в ультра-левые группировки и даже участвовал в 'баррикадных' боях в Париже в 1968 году. Возможно, он, осознавая свою 'не-героическую пассивность' во время войны, испытывал чувство вины за Холокост, происходивший на его глазах при полном равнодушии французского общества.

summary.capture: Рефлексия о стыде и концепция Другого
summary.text: Сартр придавал большое значение концепции 'стыда' в отношениях с Другим. Стыд открывает перед субъектом повседневный аспект его жизни, который незначим, пока не появляется Другой. Взгляд Другого лишает субъекта идентичности и свободы, вынуждая его существовать под перекрестком двух взглядов: своего и Другого.

Возможно, из-за чувства стыда и неспособности к активному сопротивлению во время войны, Сартр ощущал потребность в компенсации. Это проявлялось в создании 'сильных' публичных жестов, которые, возможно, позволяли ему пережить ужас перед властью в ослабленной форме. Например, предоставление страниц своего журнала 'Тан Модерн' авторам с противоположными убеждениями может служить примером таких 'великодушных' действий.

Чувство вины за страх и неспособность к активному сопротивлению во время войны привели к формированию 'онтологической вины' у Сартра. Это чувство глубокой вины реализовалось в поиске и легитимации множественных Других, лишенных своего дискурса в европейской культуре, через усиленные усилия Сартра.

summary.capture: Дискурсы вины после Второй мировой войны
summary.text: Вторая мировая война и Холокост стали источниками формирования 'дискурса вины' в европейской культуре второй половины ХХ века. Сартр оставался активно вовлеченным в темы и мотивы войны, рассматривая их с точки зрения психоанализа и делая их центральными в своем творчестве.

capture: The Beginning of second order cybernetics. S.A. Umpleby, T.A. Medvedeva
description: The article discusses the emergence of second-order cybernetics based on work in experimental epistemology and the study of the nervous system, as well as the emergence of a new understanding of the cognitive process. Studies have shown that it is necessary to include a scientist-observer in the description of the system, since his or her specific characteristics and subjective worldview can influence the result of observation. The authors give examples of neurophysiological experiments that served as the basis for the conclusion that knowledge is a biological phenomenon, that each individual constructs his own "reality", which is consistent with the world of sensory experience, but is not identical to it.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of Social Science Department

summary.text: The article discusses the emergence of second-order cybernetics based on work in experimental epistemology and the study of the nervous system, as well as the emergence of a new understanding of the cognitive process. Studies have shown that it is necessary to include a scientist-observer in the description of the system, since his or her specific characteristics and subjective worldview can influence the result of observation. The authors give examples of neurophysiological experiments that served as the basis for the conclusion that knowledge is a biological phenomenon, that each individual constructs his own 'reality', which is consistent with the world of sensory experience, but is not identical to it.

summary.capture: Two Ways of Understanding Cybernetics of Higher Orders
summary.text: Two ways of understanding cybernetics of higher orders are considered. The first interpretation emphasizes that higher orders of cybernetics can be based on the introduction of additional dimensions (for example, second-order cybernetics relies on neurophysiology, third-order cybernetics takes into account data from sociology and political science, fourth-order cybernetics uses data related to the environment and social responsibility). The second interpretation is based on the opinion that there is no need for cybernetics of higher orders, since the observer himself can define any system of interest to him (for example, a group within an organization, society or the environment) and create any number of additional descriptions (H. von Förster).

The authors of the article conclude that second-order cybernetics offers a higher conceptual level by drawing attention to the scientist (observer). Second order cybernetics leads to second order science. It points to a suitable epistemology for an information society. The inclusion of the scientist (observer) in observations changes the epistemological foundation of science.

The birth of cybernetics as a scientific discipline in the United States is usually associated with the publication of two papers in 1943. Rosenblueth, Wiener, Bigelow, in 'Behavior, Purpose, Teleology', argued that goal-setting and purposeful human activity can be performed by machines specially created for this purpose. The authors of the second article, by Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts, 'A Logical Calculus of the Ideas Immanent in Nervous Activity,' suggested that ideas emerge through the activity of a neural network.

Applications of these ideas have been developed for many systems: mechanical (James Watt), electrical (Norbert Wiener), biological (Walter B. Cannon), psychological (Warren McCulloch), political (Karl Deutsch), organizational (Stafford Beer), etc. How did scientists from such different disciplines come to understand the need to apply the ideas of cybernetics in their scientific fields?

In 1974, Heinz von Foerster explained the phenomenon of applying cybernetics in different disciplines using the term 'second-order cybernetics'. He drew on earlier work in the field of experimental epistemology by Warren McCulloch (1965), as well as work in mathematics by Norbert Wiener (1948). Common to all these areas of application is that they include two objects - the observer and the system observed, since it was found that the specific characteristics of the scientist/observer and his subjective worldview can influence the results of observations. In subsequent years, von Foerster and his colleagues tried to establish this new or updated concept of cybernetics, but these ideas did not have a strong impact on the broad scientific community.

summary.capture: NEUROPHYSIOLOGICAL FOUNDATIONS OF SECOND ORDER CYBERNETICS
summary.text: The development of the basic idea of second-order cybernetics took place in the works of von Förster (1981), E. von Glasersfeld (1987), H. Maturana and F. Varela (1987). They argued that knowledge is a biological phenomenon, that each individual constructs his own "reality" [Foerster 1974; 2003] and that knowledge is “consistent” with the world of sensory experience, but not “identical” to it [Glasersfeld 1987].

The basis for such conclusions was the neurophysiological experiments that were carried out by W. McCulloch, H. Maturana, F. Varela, and others. The “Blind Spot” experiment is widely known, demonstrating that local blindness is a consequence of the absence of photoreceptors. In another experiment, two kittens are placed in bags on a cart. One of them has its paws tucked in, while the other is standing. Then the cart is moved for several days. After that, the kittens are taken out of the bags and placed on a table. One kitten moves normally, the other walks off the edge of the table. The kittens are lowered to the floor. One of them walks normally, the other bumps into things as if he can't see anything. The kitten that was standing on the cart can see and move normally. The kitten that was not standing lacked depth perception [Held and Hein 1963].

There are many ways the brain helps us. For example, if we listen to a foreign lecturer delivering a lecture in our native language with an accent, then we must listen very intensely to understand this accent. However, after 10-15 minutes, the brain learns the algorithm, and we no longer must work so hard to understand the speaker.

During the war, soldiers were sometimes injured by high-velocity projectiles to the head but remained alive. The nature of these wounds was such that most lesions were well-localized occipital lesions in the brain that heal relatively quickly without the patient realizing any noticeable loss of vision. The doctors expected to see apparent motor dysfunction. Clinical trials showed that the motor system was in order, but in some cases, there was a significant loss of a large part of the visual field [Foerster 1973]. Doctors could not find an explanation for what was happening. But an incident occurred that helped in understanding the situation and in finding a way to treat the patients. One of the doctors came to his patient to ask a series of questions and wrote down the answers to them. During the conversation, the doctor put down his pen, took out a pack of cigarettes and invited the patient to smoke. The patient accepted the offer but did not reach for a cigarette. The doctor repeated the invitation to smoke again and held out the cigarette more insistently. The patient looked at the doctor inquiringly and asked where the cigarette was. The doctor replied that he held it in his hand. The patient said it was not there. The doctor asked what was in his hand. The patient replied, “a pen.” The field of vision of the wounded soldiers was limited. When the doctor entered the room, the patient saw him in his peripheral vision, and thus the patient's brain gathered data about what was happening. But, when the patient looked at the doctor, the middle fell out of his field of vision because there was a blind spot. The patient's brain constructed reality based on the data it already had.

A successful therapy was found. It consisted of blindfolding the patient for one to two months until he regained control of his motor system, switching his "attention" from "non-existent" visual cues to "fully working” channels that provide direct information from 'sensors' embedded in muscles and joints. Von Förster writes: “Let us once again note that the patients did not perceive the “lack of perception”, as well as the emergence of perception through sensory-motor interaction. This evokes two metaphors: "Perception is action" and "If I do not see that I am blind, I am blind, but if I see that I am blind, then I see" [Foerster 1973].

Second order cybernetics offers a higher conceptual level by drawing attention to the scientist (observer). The higher order refers to the scientist's act of observation. An observer can define any system of interest to him (for example, a group within an organization, a society, or an environment) and create any number of additional descriptions. The idea that each 'order' of cybernetics is rooted in a separate theoretical discipline is one interpretation of second-order cybernetics, but it is important that second-order cybernetics requires a different level of analysis, a different philosophy, a different theory of knowledge, and not just a different theory.

Second order cybernetics leads to second order science. If physics is a fundamental field that describes the relationship between matter and energy, then cybernetics is a fundamental field that describes control and communication. Physics became the basis of industrial society. Cybernetics provides the basis for an information society. Second-order cybernetics points to a suitable theory of knowledge for an information society. The inclusion of a scientist (observer) in descriptions changes the epistemological foundation of science. The epistemology of realism is supplemented by the epistemology of constructivism in the works of some scientists in the USA and Europe.

capture: Как копеечная экономия сохраняет миллионы. Микростандарты.
description:
Внимание: сегодня вы можете пройти тест и получить сертификат от автора канала.

     Мелочи в конструкциях, технологиях и логистики, на которые часто просто не обращают внимание, могут дать существенную экономию, если она работают на больших объемах.

     Пример
     На заводе Форда в Детройте, было сделано замечательное изобретение. Обычно бамперы автомобилей хромировали в гальванических ваннах и наносили слой хром в 0,25 мм. Функция этого слоя простая – не допускать влагу к основному металлу, стали, чтобы защитить ее от коррозии.
       Предложение было простым и эффективным – сделать слой хрома в 5 раз меньше, ведь на функцию защиты толщина слоя не влияет, а с учетом большого количества  хромируемых изделий экономия получилась недетской.
        А почему же сразу не сделали тонкий слой?
        Об этом вы узнаете  в видео, а заодно получите хороший навык, как экономить большие деньги на мелочах.

       Напоминаю: для удобства я ввел кнопку подписки на канал:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCq5Q2YWtZYnOHFe3ZO1MZRw?sub_confirmation=1 

чтобы вы могли вовремя получать новые материалы.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of Social Science Department

summary.text: Долгое время контакты электрических лампочек соединялись с цоколем пайкой. Однако в 1990 году инженер предложил заменить пайку на контактную сварку, что позволило экономить 0.8 г припоя на каждой лампочке. При производстве около 500 миллионов лампочек экономия составила около 40 тонн припоя.

Инженер предложил уменьшить слой хрома, который наносился на бамперы автомобилей, в 5 раз. Изначально толстый слой хрома наносился из-за нестабильности процесса гальванизации. После улучшения технологии удалось в 5 раз уменьшить толщину слоя хрома, что привело к экономии дорогостоящего металла и ускорению процесса.

Долгое время в авиации существовало правило, согласно которому самолёт должен был садиться против ветра. Это было обусловлено тем, что встречный ветер сокращал длину посадочной полосы, особенно для лёгких самолётов с посадочной скоростью 50-80 км/ч. Однако современные самолёты с огромной массой и посадочной скоростью 250-300 км/ч испытывают меньшее влияние ветра на длину посадочного пробега. Введённое правило приводило к излишнему расходу горючего из-за необходимости разворота для посадки против ветра.

Недавно было введено изменение, разрешающее садиться в любом положении, за исключением бокового ветра, который остаётся опасным. Это изменение позволяет избежать излишних разворотов и экономить горючее.

В некоторых штатах США водителям разрешено поворачивать направо на красный свет после остановки и пропуска потока машин. Это правило разгружает дороги и экономит время, позволяя водителям сразу поворачивать на красный свет, вместо ожидания.

Водителям грузовиков было предложено прокладывать маршруты так, чтобы избегать левых поворотов. Это позволило не только экономить время, но и снизить расходы на топливо, так как машины больше не стояли на перекрёстках.

При проведении функционально-стоимостного анализа важно тщательно проанализировать даже мелкие возможные изменения или замены в технологиях, чтобы добиться экономии без ущерба для функциональности системы.

Каждый раз при проведении операции в Bank of America выдается чек. Один из инженеров заметил, что изменение шрифта и расположения информации на чеке может значительно сократить его размер, что привело к экономии около полумиллиона долларов только на кассовой бумаге. Аналогично, студент колледжа предложил заменить шрифт на распечатываемых документах, что принесло экономию на чернилах в размере 21000 долларов. Эта идея была распространена на многие учреждения, и общая экономия только от замены шрифта оказалась 136 миллионов долларов.
В 2008 году в сети ресторанов была проведена экономия путем убирания одной пластинки сыра из бургера, что позволило сэкономить до полумиллиона долларов в год.

Замена материалов в различных устройствах и оборудовании может привести к существенной экономии. Например, замена бронзовых или стальных гаек на смесителях на кухнях на гайки из полипропилена привела к упрощению процесса замены и сэкономила значительные трудозатраты.
Экономия возможна за счет оптимизации расходов на материалы и ресурсы, а также за счет тщательного анализа и внедрения инновационных решений, которые не ущемляют интересы клиентов.
достаточно чтобы смеситель прочно сидел на раковине. Так что как видите замена и привела к удешевлению и е дополнительные пирожки бонус смеситель стало легче менять.

аналогичная ситуация была с болтами крепления сиденья унитаза на самом унитазе. Дело в том что раньше это были бронзовые болты и бронзовые болты с бронзовыми гайками за несколько лет эксплуатации соединялись настолько прочно что очень было опасно их удалять ну просто можно было повредить унитаз. А вот полипропиленовых болтов позволило в общем-то устранить этот недостаток они достаточно прочные чтобы сиденья хорошо держалась на унитазе. Ну а когда вам надо поменять вы их легко развинчивания вы берёте обыкновенную дрель и аккуратно просверливают. Этот болт и он легко удалится то есть стало и дешевле и подведём итоги в нашей жизни постоянно появляются новые материалы новые технологии и очень тщательно надо следить за тем чтобы психологическая инерция не мешала вам экономить какие-то.

Ну пусть вам кажется не очень большие средства на одном изделии. Но если этих изделий очень много то копеечное на одном издели экономия может сэкономить вам большие большие средства сегодня всё если вам понравилась лекция ставьте лайки подписывайтесь на канал рекомендуйте его вашим друзьям. Всего доброго.

capture: What will the 10 LARGEST States be in 2050?
description:
Where will America's 10 Biggest States by Population be in 2050? 

The United States is projected to reach its peak population of around 370million by 2080. And the way our population is distributed will change drastically in the coming decades too, with "Everyone" leaving many of the most overcrowded states for some of the emptiest states! In search for a good economy and jobs, warmer weather, more space, or a cheaper cost of living.

By 2050, it's estimated that 60% of Americans will live in the 10 Most Populous States. Will they be among the Fastest Growing or Shrinking? Perhaps the Best or Worst States to move to? And what social, economic and infrastructure challenges will the USA face between now and then?

➽ Join our OFFICIAL Discord Server!: https://discord.gg/r2aYWeaXeq

And while many of these states offer GREAT big cities to live in, if you're trying to homestead, buy cheap, empty land, or just wanna live in the middle of nowhere... certain already empty states, will shrink DRASTICALLY by 2100 too! So my biggest suggestion is to visit these cities, towns, and states before you decide where you want to move to and live!

summary.capture: Population Projection for the United States
summary.text: The US's population is projected to peak at 370 million residents in 2080. By 2050, it's estimated that 90% of the population will live in cities and 60% will live in just 10 states.

Washington has been one of the fastest growing states, with its population jumping from 4.87 million residents in 1990 to 8 million today. The Seattle area has had one of the best economies for decades, with a median household income of $102,000, being the third highest of any metro. The region is predicted to welcome an additional 1.2 million jobs and 1.8 million residents by 2050. The state is projected to add 2.4 million residents by 2050, bringing the total population to 10.4 million.

Illinois peaked at 12.9 million residents and was the fifth most populous state in 2013. However, it has been losing residents for 10 straight years, with a net 104,000 residents leaving the state in 2022. The decline is attributed to high taxes, crime, traffic, weather, and an increasing cost of living, particularly in the Chicago metro area.

Ohio is perhaps the most misunderstood and disrespected state, quietly housing the nation's seventh largest population and economy. Ohio's population of 11.76 million is shrinking, but by much less than its contemporaries. Over half of total moves in the state being inbound migration is an indication of what's to come. The state is still exceptionally cheap and Columbus's diverse job market is expanding rapidly. The government is implementing incentives to convince people to stay, with $1 billion already invested in infrastructure and broadband expansion to attract new tech companies. A brand new merit scholarship program provides $5,000 to the top 5% of students who choose to attend an Ohio University. Despite people fleeing certain cities due to high crime and lack of good paying jobs, Ohio's population is projected to remain fairly stagnant with 11.82% residents in 2050.

Pennsylvania's demographics will shift dramatically over the next 30 years. New data suggests the amount of under 20-year-olds dropping by hundreds of thousands in the coming decades, but seniors are settling in rural areas due to Pennsylvania having many of the best small towns.
Overall Pennsylvania is expected to grow from 12.97% in the fifth most populous state today to 13.2 million in 2050.

Georgia's population is more than tripled over the past 70 years from 3.44 million in 1950 to nearly 11 million today. The state is still attracting many newcomers mainly because of Atlanta's exceptional job market. Atlanta's Metro population has already doubled in just the past 25 years to 6.24 million. The Atlanta Regional Commission foresees the region growing by an additional 38% to reach 8.6 million residents by 2050.

North Carolina is projected to increase by 23.4% over the next 27 years to 13.55 million. It is projected to make the greatest jump on this list from 10.82 million residents in ninth place today to over 14 million residents and fifth place by 2050. Charlotte is expeditiously expanding with the metro area poised to see a 37.8% population gain from 2.76 million today to 3.8 million by 2050. Raleigh with its Metro population of 1.48 million is projected to add another million new residents by 2050.
New York would likely be the...

New York State has experienced fluctuations in its population over the years. Despite losing over 500,000 residents since 2020, the state had gained over 600,000 new residents from 2018 to 2020. Many New Yorkers who fled due to the pandemic sought more space or to live closer to family, with New Jersey and Connecticut receiving the majority. However, the city saw an increase in residents last year, with projections indicating a 8.2% growth in the NYC Metro population to reach 21.15 million by 2050. The state is estimated to reach 20.83 million residents in 2050.

Florida is currently the fastest growing state, with a population of 22.63 million increasing by 1.61% over the past year. It is predicted to welcome 3 to 400,000 new residents per year for at least the next decade. The Tampa Bay Region is expected to grow by over 43% from 3.29 million residents today to 4.71 million by 2050. Florida is poised to become the third ever state to hit 30 million residents with a projected population of 31.19 million in 2050, provided rising ocean levels do not force people to flee.

Arizona's population is expected to grow dramatically by 2050, with the Phoenix Metro Area alone projected to have a population greater than 7.5 million. The state as a whole is estimated to have around 10.12 million residents by mid-century, making it the 12th largest state by population. Arizona is on track to make the top 10 by 2100, provided water and energy concerns with the increasing population are addressed.

California, currently the most populous state, has experienced a decline in population over the past few years due to factors such as expensive cost of living, COVID restrictions, and the ability to work from home. Despite this, the state's population is projected to stabilize and experience a 1.46% increase over the next 27 years, reaching 39.51 million.

Texas is projected to become the largest state by population by 2050, surpassing California. With its affordable cost of living, moderate weather, and strong economies in its largest cities, Texas is expected to be the fastest growing state over the next 30 years, housing an estimated 30.74 million residents currently.

Dallas Fort Worth Metro is poised to pass Los Angeles to become the second largest with a population of 14 million. The Houston Metro should see around a 33% increase to reach 10.4 million residents. The Austin and San Antonio metros, which will likely have merged to become one massive Metroplex, are expected to add an additional 3 million residents for a total of 8.3 million overall.
Texas's population in 2050 is estimated to be 4.22 million. This means Texas will hold 12.2% of the US population. Over 50% of Americans currently live in just nine states.

capture: Cybersecurity Architecture: Five Principles to Follow (and One to Avoid)
description:
IBM Security QRadar EDR : https://ibm.biz/Bdyd7k

IBM Security X-Force Threat Intelligence Index 2023: https://ibm.biz/Bdyd76

This ten part video series is based on a 400 level class on Enterprise Cybersecurity Architecture  taught by Jeff "the Security Guy" Crume at a local university. He'll begin by explaining the foundational principles of cybersecurity - five that are best practices and one that's just the opposite. The subsequent episodes will look at the various domains that apply to a well-designed security architecture. Be sure to subscribe so you'll get notified of the next video!

Get started for free on IBM Cloud → https://ibm.biz/ibm-cloud-sign-up

Subscribe to see more videos like this in the future → http://ibm.biz/subscribe-now

#AI #Software #ITModernization #Cybersecurity #QRadar #JeffCrume #ibm 

Chapters
00:00 Principles Introduction
01:05 Defense in Depth
04:20 Least Privilege
07:55 Separation of Duties
09:50 Secure by Design
12:15 Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS)
14:43 Security by Obscurity

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.text: With the rise of cyberattacks and data breaches, it's never been more important to make sure that your organization is protected against hackers. This series is about cybersecurity architecture, and we're going to talk about two different areas. Fundamentals, where we're going to go through and discover what some of the principles of cybersecurity are that need to be applied to everything that you do. And then the second part is on various cybersecurity domains. Here we're going to explore how to identify vulnerabilities, implement best practices, and defend against a wide range of cyber threats through an all encompassing cybersecurity architecture.

By the way, I'm an adjunct professor at NC State University. And there I teach a 400 level course on enterprise security architecture. This video series is based upon that course. The bad news is you won't get college credit for watching these videos. The good news is no homework and no exams. So yay.

All right, let's get started with cybersecurity fundamentals. All right, we want to start with five security principles that you absolutely should do and one that you never should do. So stay tuned to the end to find out what that one is. The first one we're going to talk about is this notion of "defense in depth". Defense in depth is trying to create an obstacle course, a difficulty for the bad guy. So if we take a look at an old security model, the castle. Well, the castle was designed with thick, tall walls to keep the good guys on the inside, the bad guys on the outside. And it worked pretty well until you realized the good guys sometimes needed to come out. And therefore, we needed to put a door on this thing. Well, the door then became a vulnerability. And so we we would try to reinforce it. And then maybe put a moat around the whole thing, because that made it even harder. And then the door with a drawbridge. So now we've got a moat, which is harder to cross. We've got the thick, tall walls. And maybe we even had in an angry dog here on this side. Something to give a system of security mechanisms, because defense in depth is all about not relying on any single security mechanism to keep the system safe. Now, let's move and transition into a modern security example. Here, we've got a user who is on a workstation who's going to go across a network to get to a web server, which is going to hit an app server, which is ultimately going to hit a database.

For defense in depth, multifactor authentication (MFA) can be implemented to verify user identity through something they have, something they are, or something they know. Mobile device management (MDM) and endpoint device management software ensure that security policies are enforced on devices, including patch management and password requirements. Additionally, next-generation antivirus (EDR) can be used for endpoint security. Firewalls are employed to secure the network and control traffic flow. Vulnerability testing is conducted on application and web servers, and data is encrypted with access controls.

The principle of least privilege dictates that access rights should only be granted to authorized individuals for the duration of their need. Access rights are justified based on business requirements. Users who do not have a business need for certain access rights should not be granted them.

The other guys get the access right. They can prove their need. I'm not going to give them this access right in perpetuity, forever. We're going to constantly be going back and making sure that they still need that capability. If they don't, we're going to remove it from them as well.

Another notion in the principle of least privilege is hardening a system. Let's say we've got a web server like this and the web server out of the box-- default configuration--is that it runs a HTTP, of course, because we need that in order to do web traffic. But let's say it also turns on an FTP service and SSH service so that I can log in remotely. Well, there's some things that I might look at and say, 'Okay, do I really need this FTP server?' If it turns out I'm not going to use it, I should remove that service entirely. In the SSH, if I'm not planning to use it, remove it entirely. Another example of hardening is to remove all of the unnecessary IDs that are on the system and change the names of the IDs that we do keep from their default.

Another example is this idea of privilege creep. Let me illustrate that. Let's say there's two people that work for the company, and each one of these are access rights that they have. This guy is able to do these things. He can do the same things because they perform essentially the same role. Now, this guy gets a promotion and a new job and new responsibilities. Well, he goes to the administrator and says, 'Okay, now I'm doing my new job. I need you to add to my capabilities. And these are the things I need.' The administrator gives him those and then also says, 'You know what? Just in case, I think you're going to probably need this. Let me give you that as well.'

The problem with this is, just-in-case is just the opposite of principle of least privilege. What we should be doing is running an annual recertification campaign. Some organizations do it more frequently than that. In re-cert, I go back and look at all of my users and all of their access rights and make sure they still have a justified need. So this person is still doing the same job, still needs all of that. This guy, though, no longer needs this capability because his new job doesn't require it. So we're taking it away. And this thing that he got just in case, we're taking that away, too. We're trying to give only the access rights you need for as long as you need them. We're going to eliminate privilege creep, and we're going to eliminate the just-in-case principle.

Our third principle to keep in mind with cybersecurity is this notion of separation of duties. We won't have any single point of control. We're trying to force collusion by two bad actors-- or more than two bad actors --in order to compromise the system. But no single person can create the compromise. An example, in the physical world, would be if I had two people here and I've got a door with two locks on it. And this guy has a key to this lock and this guy has a key to this lock. If he uses his key to open the door, he still can't open the door. He can't open the door alone. But the two of them together, cooperating, can in fact, open the door. There's no single point of control. Therefore, we have a separation of duties. Taking a look at another example here, in an IT case, here's a requester. This user wants access to this database. So he's going to ask for that. Then there's an approver who's going to have to take action on it and say yes or no based upon whether we think they should have it or not. Then if they get the approval, then they're given the action that they want.

The principles of least privilege, elimination of privilege creep, and separation of duties are crucial in maintaining cybersecurity. By adhering to these principles, organizations can minimize the risk of unauthorized access and compromise of their systems.
This person, the requester, is not the same as the approver. They cannot be the same person. Because if it was, if I could request and approve my own request, then there is no separation of duties.

What we're trying to do with this is create a necessary case for collusion, which is hard to do because it's hard for lots of people to work together and keep a good secret. And what we're trying to avoid is this single point of control.

The fourth security principle that we're going to talk about is secure by design. In other words, it shouldn't be an afterthought that we put security in. Think of it this way: If you were designing a building in an earthquake zone, you want to make this building able to stand the pressure. So, you don't go build the building, and then after it's all done, go back and say, "Now let's make it earthquake-proof". No, you want to do that from start-to-finish, all the way from design through completion.

So let's take a look at an IT example. So when we have a project, we will tend to start off with requirements stage. We'll go then into design, we will code the thing, then we'll install whatever it is that we've written, then we'll test it out and then we'll promote it to production. And then, in theory, we should feed that loop back and continue the continuous development process that way. Well, what we don't want to do, is what too many people do in these cases, and they wait until really about this phase to do security--once it's already out there. Security can't just be a bolt-on that you do at the end. In fact, it needs to be something that we're doing throughout, pervasively. We look at the security aspects of the requirements. We build security into the design. We are thinking about secure coding principles all along the path. When we install, we do it on a secure system. We're testing and and guarding that test data. And then in production, obviously, we keep testing. So security is something we do throughout, but it doesn't begin here. It begins in these phases. That's what we're really looking for here.

Now, if you think about another example, let's say: Whose job is security? Well, it's really everyone here. We have a designer, an administrator and a user. So really, all of them are responsible for security in one way or another. But who does the job begin with? Well, it begins with this guy right here.

We need to make sure that he is designing security in. In other words, what we're trying to do is make security start to finish. And we want "secure by design", means it's secure out of the box. That's the way we'd like it to be. Now, sometimes we're going to have to do some configuration changes to make it more secure. But this is the goal that we're trying to shoot for--secure by design, secure out of the box.

Our fifth security principle is the "K.I.S.S. principle". It stands for "Keep It Simple, Stupid". In other words, we don't want to make it harder than necessary because that will make it easier for the bad guys and harder for the good guys. To give you an example: we're trying to create some level of complexity so that it's not easy for the bad guy to get in. But a lot of times the security department will create this complex maze of things that the good guys essentially have to go through. And what happens in that case is, I start in here, okay, I log in. Now, I have to traverse and eventually I'm like, "Oh, I'm at a dead end". Okay, maybe let's try this again. You know what? It's too much trouble to do what the security department has asked me to do. I'm just going to subvert this, and I'm going to end up doing it that way, which is, of course, not what we're after. So the lesson here is, if we make it harder to do the right thing than it is to do the wrong thing, people are going to do the wrong thing. So we need to be able to make the system secure, but also as simple as possible. So keep it simple, stupid.

Here's an example of how we do this in security departments, for real. We'll come up with password rules. So we'll say this is your password and it equals this. And it's this because we created a complex set of rules that say you have to start with an uppercase, then you follow with a lowercase, then you need a special character, then you need to throw in some numbers, and then you have to have some mixture of upper and lower case and special characters and all this kind of stuff. And it has to be really long. And by the way, we need lots of these. You're going to have a different one on every system, and I'm going to make you change it on a frequent basis. That's this-- that's what the user sees --is a complex maze, and they're going to find a way to do this.

What we want to do is understand complexity is the enemy of security. We want to make the system just complex enough to keep the bad guys out, but not so complex that it's hard for the good guys to do what they need to do.

There might be some conflict in that because there we're trying to set a system of security mechanisms in place to put an obstacle course for the bad guy. We want that obstacle course to be for the bad guy, not for the good guy.

Now we've gone over five security principles that you should always observe. And now the big reveal, the security principle you should never observe, and that is security by obscurity. It turns out that secrecy and security are not the same thing.

This guy called Kerckhoff came up with what's now known as Kerckhoff's Principle, which basically describes that. He was specifically talking about a crypto system. A crypto system should be secure if you know every single thing about it except for the key. In other words, the key is the only secret in the whole system.

summary.capture: Black Box vs. Glass Box Security
summary.text: What we want is not black box security, we want glass box security.

In this case, the clear text is processed by well-known crypto algorithms such as AES and RSA. These algorithms are publicly available for anyone to understand and analyze. The security of the encryption does not rely on keeping the algorithm itself secret, but rather on the secrecy of the key.

The key is the only secret component in the encryption process. It is essential for ensuring the security of the encrypted data. This emphasizes the significance of maintaining the secrecy of the key in cryptographic systems.

The discussion highlights that security based solely on secrecy, whether in encryption algorithms or operating systems, is not reliable. Emphasizing the importance of secrecy alone does not guarantee robust security.

The video concludes by emphasizing the importance of key secrecy in cryptographic systems and the limitations of relying solely on secrecy for security. It also encourages viewers to subscribe for future cybersecurity architecture series updates.

capture: Theories: Why are they important? What are they for? Why should I care about them?
description: Role of Theory in Scientific Enterprise. The Process of Theory Building. Theory Pruning. Diverse Paths to Theory Building.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.capture: Role of Theory in Scientific Enterprise
summary.text: Theory plays a critical role in the broader scientific enterprise, particularly in management science. It is essential for getting papers published in the top journals as they prioritize contributions to theory. Editors and reviewers assess the contribution to theory when evaluating papers. A theory is essentially an explanation of organizational phenomena, such as employee turnover or job performance. Therefore, the goal of management researchers is to understand organizations and individual behavior, which necessitates the development of theories and explanations.

The process of theory building is intriguing due to the need to develop more theories to explain various phenomena. However, there is also an issue of unnecessary proliferation of theories because they are rarely proven false. The work of philosophers of science, like Karl Popper, emphasized falsification as a critical criterion for a good theory. However, few researchers are known for proving that a theory doesn't work, leading to a lack of falsifiability in many theories.

We have more and more theories building up, but few theories are being disproven and falsified. There is a need to cut down the very large number of theories that exist at this point. Is it possible to issue theory limitations in articles? Our role as researchers is to understand what is going on and to create, build, and test theories. However, the way we arrive at a theory could be through different paths, not just the hypothetic-deductive way.
The process of arriving at a theory can involve inductive procedures and starting with a research question that might eventually lead to theory building or creating, as opposed to theory testing.

capture: Why GraphQL Needs API Management
description: API management is crucial, particularly for GraphQL APIs. It handles access control, usage statistics, rate limiting, and developer portals. In this video, developer advocate Roy Derks presents reasons why API developers consider API management to help with these concerns, especially for GraphQL APIs.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of WEB Technology Department

summary.text: When you're developing an API, you probably thought about adding API management to handle things like access control, usage stats, rate limiting, and developer portals. This is especially important when you're developing a GraphQL API.

In GraphQL, the end user has control over the data they retrieve from the API by sending a document containing an operation and a list of fields. They can basically retrieve all the data they want, and this is important when you're looking at rate limiting.

When you want to do rate limiting for a GraphQL API, it's useful to do a query cost analysis. This is where you would look at all the underlying services of your GraphQL API and assign weights to those services. For example, collecting data from a database or a REST API might be more efficient than collecting data from a SOAP API. By adding weights to these different data sources, you'll be able to handle rate limiting.

Instead of looking at complexity, such as the query cost analysis, you can also handle rate limiting based on a certain number of requests per second, minute, or hour. Additionally, you can do rate limiting based on the maximum complexity, which would be the complexity from your query cost analysis, or by looking at the query depth. The query depth refers to the number of fields and nested fields a user is requesting from your API.

A GraphQL API often comes with a built-in playground or explorer called GraphiQL. This provides users with a way to interact with the API and explore the GraphQL schema. However, it's important to note that the playground or explorer is not a substitution for documentation.
By adding API management, you can handle documentation, usage stats, and even access control. API management enhances the experience for people building GraphQL APIs.

In this video, we looked at why you might need API management for your API, especially when building GraphQL APIs. API management helps with query cost analysis for rate limiting and enhances the overall experience for developers. If you liked this video and want to see more like it, please like and subscribe. If you have any questions, please drop them in the comments below.

capture: GraphQL vs REST: Which is Better for APIs? IBM Technology
description: If you're a developer, you're probably familiar with REST APIs, but there's another query language for APIs that you should add to your programming toolkit:  GraphQL. In this video, Martin explains the two different approaches these frameworks take for building APIs and compares their strengths and weaknesses. Spoiler alert: It's not an either/or choice, and it's worth knowing both approaches and applying them where it makes the most sense.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of WEB Technology Department

summary.text: So, I have these two colleagues let's call them 'R', and then we'll call the other one 'G'. Just using initials here to protect our identities. Now, R is rather talkative. They tell you everything they know, whether you want to hear it or not. G, on the other hand, is much more reserved. They share the information that's absolutely necessary, but no more. But they're always willing to share more if I do ask. And look, this is one way that we can think of the differences between REST, that's the 'R', and GraphQL, that's the 'G'. REST can be a bit of a know-it-all. You have to be specific in your requests and sift through all the data that's returned. With GraphQL, you can be precise and only retrieve the data you need. So that GraphQL prioritizes, giving clients exactly the data they request and no more. But I'm getting ahead of myself here. What clients? What do these technologies do?

Well, both REST and GraphQL are used to build something called APIs, or Application Programming Interfaces. And those allow different applications to communicate with each other over the Internet. So an API takes requests from a client over here, and a client can be like a web application or a mobile app or something like that, and then it retrieves the necessary data from a server over here.

Now REST, or 'REpresentational State Transfer' is an architectural style that relies on HTTP requests to interact with resources. It uses HTTP methods like Get, Put, Post, and Delete to access resources. A client can request a response using these methods, and the server responds with a representation of the resource in a format like JSON or XML. REST also allows clients to filter, sort, and paginate the data using query parameters.

On the other hand, GraphQL is a query language that allows clients to retrieve data from multiple data sources in a single API call. In GraphQL, we have a 'schema' which defines all the possible data that clients can query through a service. A 'query' is a request for data that follows the structure defined in the schema. The data requested in the query is retrieved by a 'resolver', which may involve fetching data from multiple sources and assembling it into a response that matches the query structure. GraphQL also has 'mutations' that allow modifying data on the server.

In GraphQL, we have a schema, queries, resolvers, and mutations. The schema defines the possible data, queries are requests for data, resolvers retrieve the data, and mutations modify data on the server. In REST, resources are the fundamental concept, each with a unique identifier called a URI. Clients can request responses using HTTP methods like Get, Put, Post, and Delete.

Both REST and GraphQL are used to build APIs that allow different applications to communicate with each other over the internet. They both use frameworks and libraries to handle network details and operate over HTTP. They can handle requests and responses using JSON or JavaScript object notation.

REST APIs return the full dataset for a resource when requested, while GraphQL allows clients to fetch only the data they need in a single request. REST APIs often require multiple requests to fetch related data, while GraphQL can fetch all the data in a single request using a complex query. REST APIs are well-suited for simple CRUD-like operations, while GraphQL is better suited for complex data requests that involve nested fields or multiple data sources.

REST and GraphQL can work together. GraphQL can be introduced on top of an existing REST API and can work with existing API management tools. Both REST and GraphQL have their unique strengths and quirks, and understanding their similarities and differences helps in choosing the right tool for the job.

capture: The flip side: Margaret Ormiston at TEDxLondonBusinessSchool
description: Choices in Daily Life. The Irony of Good Behavior. Consequences in Morality. Moral Licensing and Behavior. Organizational Moral Licensing. Socially Responsible Activities and Irresponsible Behavior. Study of Fortune 500 Companies. Moral Licensing Effect. Negative Consequence of CSR. Addressing the Issue. Board Governance. Personal Responsibility. Commitment to Corporate Social Responsibility.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.text: Every day, we make choices in life, ranging from mundane decisions to those of great consequence. Let's start with a mundane example. Consider a person faced with the choice between an apple and fast food. This type of decision is relatable to all of us, as we encounter similar choices daily. Often, we may choose the healthier option, feeling good about our decision and considering ourselves to be healthy individuals. However, this can lead to a subsequent belief that we deserve a reward for our good behavior, which may result in making less healthy choices later.

Research indicates an ironic effect of engaging in good behavior leading to engaging in bad behavior. A study demonstrated that individuals who were given a supposedly good thing, such as a multivitamin, were more likely to engage in hedonic activities, including smoking, drinking, eating junk food, and avoiding exercise. This phenomenon extends beyond dietary choices to other aspects of life, such as exercise and work habits.

The phenomenon of good behavior leading to subsequent bad behavior is not limited to trivial decisions but also extends to domains of great consequence, including morality. Studies have shown that individuals who were given opportunities to affirm their lack of sexist beliefs were more likely to express sexist views and beliefs. This demonstrates the far-reaching impact of the ironic effect of good behavior leading to undesirable outcomes.

In a recent study, Dr. Kucho Key found that engaging in moral behavior can lead individuals to subsequently engage in morally questionable activities. This phenomenon, termed moral licensing, suggests that by accruing moral credits, individuals feel comfortable engaging in morally questionable behavior without feeling like a bad person.

Research by Elaine Wong and colleagues aimed to understand if organizations also exhibit moral licensing behavior. Past research indicates that companies engaging in wrongdoing are more likely to subsequently engage in socially irresponsible actions. For example, companies with bad reputations for social responsibility were found to be the most likely to donate money to charities after a natural disaster, possibly to compensate for their negative reputation.

summary.capture: Socially Responsible Activities and Irresponsible Behavior
summary.text: The pendulum swing between engaging in socially responsible activities and subsequently engaging in irresponsible behavior towards stakeholders is a phenomenon observed in various companies. Examples include Enron, known for a large corporate scandal despite its philanthropic reputation, and BP, which focused on safety initiatives before the deepwater oil spill in 2010. Research suggests that top leaders' strategic decisions impact this trend, as they may feel more licensed to engage in irresponsible behavior after implementing socially responsible programs. Employees may also feel vicariously licensed to mistreat stakeholders when observing their leaders' actions.

A study of Fortune 500 companies revealed that those engaging in more social responsibility activities were subsequently more likely to engage in irresponsible behavior towards stakeholders. For every five positive actions towards stakeholders, these companies were more likely to take one negative action. Additionally, CEOs who projected a moral image in the media were found to play a significant role in this trend.

Companies that put forth a moral image into the media are most likely to suffer from the moral licensing effect, leading to engagement in irresponsible behavior after a good year of corporate social responsibility (CSR). CEOs with a moral piggy bank mentality may feel comfortable engaging in mistreatment towards stakeholders when they perceive they have achieved a sweet spot.
Engaging in CSR can lead to subsequent engagement in irresponsible behavior at an organizational level, creating a negative consequence.

Instead of turning away from CSR, efforts should focus on ameliorating the relationship between CSR and irresponsible behavior. This can be achieved through improved board governance and personal responsibility.
Boards should actively monitor CEOs and the top management team after a good year of CSR, ensuring continued efforts towards corporate social responsibility.
Individuals need to take personal responsibility to prevent irresponsible behavior, reframing the importance of commitment to becoming a more healthy person.
Commit ourselves to be leading an organization or a team where we really value corporate social responsibility. Thank you.

In the event of a catastrophe, protecting knowledge is crucial. The story of the Library of Alexandria illustrates the setback caused by the loss of knowledge. capture: How To Install PrivateGPT - Chat With PDF, TXT, and CSV Files Privately! (Quick Setup Guide)
description: Private GPT Overview. Installation Instructions. Customization. Downloading and Setting Up Models. Loading Source Documents. Ingesting Files. Running the Application. Installation of Private GPT. Video Appreciation.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.text: Private GPT is a new project currently the number one trending project on GitHub. It allows users to load up documents, text files, and PDF files and ask questions about them using a large language model. The best part is it's completely private, open source, and doesn't require sending information to any external sources. It can be installed locally on a machine and used without an internet connection. It uses one of the recent GPT for all models and works quite well.

To install Private GPT, open Visual Studio code, click on 'File' in the top left, then 'New Window'. Click the toggle panel button in the top right to open a terminal. Next, go to the GitHub repo, click the green code button, and copy the URL. Switch back to Visual Studio code, change directories to the desktop, and use 'git clone' followed by the URL to clone it to the desktop. Navigate to the folder and open it in Visual Studio code. Install the requirements by typing 'pip install -r requirements.txt' and hit enter. Rename the file 'example.nf' to just '.m'. This sets up the environment variables needed to run Private GPT.
The 'example.nf' file allows for customization of settings if needed. However, default settings are used in the provided instructions.

To get started, download the ggml GPT for all J version 1.3 groovy and the ggml model Q4 underscore zero dot bin files from the GitHub repo page. These files are quite large, so be prepared for a lengthy download. Once downloaded, create a folder called 'models' and move the downloaded files into this folder.

After setting up the models, load the files you want to ask questions about into the 'Source documents' folder. This can include text files, PDF files, and CSV files. For example, you can use the 'State of the Union dot text' file, which contains the recent State of the Union Address.

Next, ingest the files by chunking them up and storing them in a database. This step is essential for using the GPT for all model to ask questions about the documents. To do this, click the 'ingest.pi' file and then click the play button. Note that this process may take a significant amount of time and put a strain on your CPU.

Finally, run the application by clicking 'privategpt.pi' and then clicking the play button. This will prompt you to enter a query, such as 'What did the president say about Russia?' The application will then provide the answer, along with any sources for the information.

That's how to install private GPT. You can run this completely locally, no internet connection required. When installing, I ran into a couple of issues around versioning and Python modules, but that only has to do with my environment. If you need help debugging anything, I just launched a Discord and you can jump in and ask for help. The link will be in the description below to that Discord.
If you like this video, please consider giving a like and subscribe. I'll see you in the next one.

summary.capture: LM Studio Installation and Model Selection
summary.text: The first and only thing you need is LM Studio, which allows you to download any open source model and run it on Windows or Mac. It comes with its own chat interface and allows you to run inference on it. To begin, visit LM studio.ai and download the version suitable for your system. After downloading, install LM Studio. Upon opening LM Studio, you can search for any model you want to use. For example, the tutorial demonstrates the use of the mistol model.

After searching for the desired model, the available versions are listed, along with details such as the blos version, number of downloads, and hearts. The tutorial recommends testing different open source models to find the best one for the intended use case. Once the preferred version is selected, such as the Q5, it can be downloaded with just a few clicks. The download process is described as quick and easy.

LM Studio not only facilitates model selection and download but also includes a chat interface and various settings for prompt format and running the models locally. The tutorial emphasizes the ease of use and the benefits of using LM Studio for model management and deployment.
To set up a local server, click the local server button and select the model to use. Then, click 'Start server' to initiate the server.

After setting up the server, the next step is to connect autogen to the server. Change the AI type to 'open AI' and point the API base to the local server (Local Host colon1 1234 V1). The API key should be null.

For executing a Python method to output numbers 1 to 100, click 'play' at the top right. The inference can be observed in LM Studio, and the logs and output can be viewed. The interaction between the assistant and user proxy can be monitored.
The main challenge is to figure out the changes required to make the system work as well as GPT 4. There are occasional issues with termination and prompt template, which need further exploration.

objections.text: The introduction lacks substantial evidence to support the claim that the instructional design portfolio bootcamp has been successful in helping people land competitive instructional design roles. It's a vague statement that could be misleading without proper data or testimonials from successful participants.

The text in this section could be perceived as promotional rather than informational. The statement that teachers have successfully transitioned into instructional design could be misleading, as it does not provide any specific examples or statistics to support this claim.

The section lacks objectivity, as it only highlights the success of Aleksandra Drobik without discussing any challenges or setbacks she may have faced during the transition process. This could potentially create unrealistic expectations for other participants.

The text seems to be leading the reader to believe that all featured freelancers get booked up quickly, which may not be the case for everyone. It fails to acknowledge the competitive nature of the market and the potential difficulties in securing freelance work.

The evaluation of Aleks' site seems to be based on personal opinion rather than objective criteria. The text does not provide any concrete metrics or standards that were used to evaluate the site's design, functionality, or success of its flagship project.

objections.capture: Lack of Comparative Analysis for Alex Hoffman's Site
objections.text: The reviewer's praise of Alex Hoffman's site is not balanced with any criticism or suggestions for improvement. Additionally, the text does not compare this site to other similar sites, making it difficult to assess the reviewer's claim about the site's quality.

objections.capture: Unsubstantiated Claims about Visual Design and Interactions
objections.text: The reviewer's statement about the visual design and interactions is vague and lacks concrete evidence. The text does not provide any specific examples to support the claim that the design is 'nice' or that the micro interactions are effective.

objections.capture: Bias in Review of Steve Chea's Portfolio
objections.text: The review of Steve Chea's portfolio appears to be biased. The reviewer's claim that the portfolio is 'distinct' and 'fun' is subjective and may reflect personal preference rather than an objective evaluation. The text also fails to provide any evidence to support the claim that the portfolio's projects are 'nice'.

The text seems to favor Nicole and Robbie's freelancing sites over others. This can be seen as unfair and prejudicial. There is no clear criteria mentioned for evaluating these sites and the author's personal opinions seem to be the basis of the assessment.
The introduction section seems to contain leading statements. The author is directing the audience to feel inspired and to find something that resonates with them, which can be seen as manipulative.

The invitation to explore section is vague and lacks specific instructions. It's unclear what the audience is supposed to do when they visit the website and what kind of content they can expect to see.

The conclusion doesn't summarize the main points of the text or provide any new insights. It simply thanks the audience for watching and promises a next video without providing any information about what the next video will cover.

summary.text: Use the CSS overview panel to better understand your page's CSS. Click Capture Overview. The report shows a summary of your page's CSS, followed by colors, font information, unused decorations, and media queries.

The Colors section groups colors by usage, like background colors and field colors. It also shows text with low-contrast issues. Click on a color to get the list of elements that use it. You can open the element in the Elements panel and fix the color there.

The Unused Declarations section lists all the styles which have no effect. For example, some declarations are unused because the height and width of an inline element are determined by its content. Clicking the Occurrences shows the affected elements.
You can always clear the overview and rerun the report, especially after applying your changes.
To learn more about the CSS overview panel, go to goo.gle/devtools-css-overview.

capture: Debugging PWA with DevTools | DevTools Tips
description: Progressive Web Apps (PWA). Implementing Web Apps. Service Workers and Offline Experience. Service Worker Lifecycle. Manifest Pane Features. Learning Resources.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.text: PWA, short for Progressive Web Apps, encompasses a group of technologies aimed at implementing advanced app experiences. Initially focused on making websites installable for easy access from home screens, PWA now includes capabilities like shortcuts, file system access, and multi-screen placement. The 'P' in PWA stands for Progressive, indicating the use of Progressive enhancement.

To make a web app installable, a manifest file is required, containing information about the app's appearance and other features. The application panel in devtools provides details about the manifest, including the app's name and icons for the home page when installed. It also ensures the availability of a maskable icon for correct display across different platforms.

Service workers act as a proxy between apps and the network, enhancing performance by managing commonly accessed static resources. They are essential for creating custom offline experiences. Workbox libraries simplify service worker routing and caching, offering modules to streamline the process. The application panel's service worker pane allows checking for registered service workers and identifying any errors.

The service worker lifecycle can be checked by visiting a specific URL on the screen. Additionally, debug options can be set to skip the service worker and check direct network responses or have new versions of the service worker take over on reload. It is also possible to check what will be served if users are offline.

The Manifest pane offers the implementation of other features such as richer install UI, shortcuts, and protocol handling. By adding a description and a set of screenshots, the app gets a richer install UI, displaying a bigger installed dialog for the PWA. Shortcuts allow users to take quick actions from the app's icon on the home screen by adding an array that includes icons and URLs to handle the actions.
To learn more about PWAs, visit web.dev/learn/pwa. For debugging PWA with DevTools, go to google.girl/dev2-pwa.

summary.text: In this video, the speaker discusses the role of an online bookkeeper, where to find jobs, and how to make money in this field. The speaker emphasizes the flexibility and independence of online bookkeeping jobs, as well as the potential salary range.

A virtual bookkeeper provides remote bookkeeping services, often working from home as a freelancer or contract labor worker. They require self-motivation, organization, and the ability to work independently. The job offers flexibility in setting hours and completing tasks.

According to salary.com, the salary range for online bookkeepers in 2021 was between thirty-nine thousand and fifty thousand dollars. The only required office equipment is a good laptop and a reliable internet connection.
