Shows you how to start the easiest and the number one most profitable business on the planet which is digital bookkeeping. Go ahead and definitely get signed up and enroll in this course. It's free so you definitely want to make sure you get this started if this is something you're definitely interested in doing.

A company or website fiverr is recommended for promoting services. Type in bookkeeper in the search box to bring up all the job postings of people offering their services. Use these as a guide to help create your own ad for offering your services to other people.

The website Upwork is recommended for finding the best people for your job and for finding online bookkeeping jobs. Type in bookkeeper to find people posting their services and jobs matching what you're looking for.

The well-known company Intuit, known for QuickBooks, offers the opportunity to become a QuickBooks Live bookkeeper and help small businesses manage their books every month. You can apply on their page and get started as a bookkeeper.

If you have the skills and experience, becoming an online bookkeeper can be an amazing opportunity. One company offering this opportunity is Bookminders, which provides weekly or monthly bookkeeping services to small businesses and non-profits. This position offers a unique opportunity for individuals, especially for moms or those with kids in school, as it requires Monday through Friday nine to five availability. Interested individuals can apply for the position by reviewing the responsibilities and requirements and submitting an application.

Bookkeeping is an excellent side hustle for working from home and increasing income. Developing high-income skills like bookkeeping can lead to achieving financial freedom faster. Additionally, there are resources available, such as a free course on becoming a bookkeeper, to help individuals gain the necessary skills and resources to succeed in this role.
The video concludes by encouraging viewers to explore a free course on becoming a bookkeeper and to subscribe to the channel for more content on increasing income.

capture: Back to the Basics. That is Bookkeeping Basics! An Intro to QuickBooks.
description: Introduction to QuickBooks Bookkeeping Basics. Goal of the Training. Instructor's Experience. Importance of Bookkeeping. Bookkeeping Overview. Entering Transactions in QuickBooks. Trial Balance and Financial Statements. Setting Up QuickBooks File. Introduction. Profit and Loss Report. Balance Sheet Report. Overview of Financial Reports. Interrelation of Reports. Double-Entry Bookkeeping. Accounting Equation and Transactions. Accounting for Transactions. Example Transaction. Overview of Transactions. Balance Sheet Analysis. Financial Management and Analysis. Understanding Financial Reports. QuickBooks Bookkeeping Basics.

meta.specTitle: Sr. Specialist of the Registrar's Office

summary.text: Hi, this is Liz with EC QuickBooks training. Welcome to Introduction to QuickBooks bookkeeping basics. Everyone wants to learn how to use QuickBooks for their business, and that's great. However, in order to use it correctly and efficiently, understanding basic bookkeeping principles is essential. This will help you understand what goes on behind the scenes in QuickBooks and what happens when you enter data in certain areas.

Our goal with this video and all of our training videos is for you to have QuickBooks success. We want you to learn how to use QuickBooks and understand how financial records will be reflected in your company file, so that you can manage your business effectively.

I am a certified pro advisor and have been using QuickBooks for over six years with clients in various industries such as construction, restaurant service, medical field, manufacturing, and retail. My bookkeeping experience spans over 14 years.

Bookkeeping is the process of recording and categorizing all transactions that flow through your business, including invoices, sales, bills, receipts, payroll, and inventory management. It is crucial to understand the basic principles of bookkeeping to enter each transaction correctly into QuickBooks, as it shows the financial health and bottom line of your company.

Let's take a look at the bookkeeping overview. We need to gather source documents such as bills, invoices, payroll information, and bank statements. These source documents must be entered into QuickBooks using the appropriate journal. QuickBooks then utilizes the set up accounts to populate the general ledger. This ledger contains all the accounts with their respective transactions, including expenses, income, and bills. Subsequently, QuickBooks generates financial statements based on the balances in these accounts.

Once the source documents are obtained, they are entered into QuickBooks using the relevant journal. The home page of QuickBooks provides access to various journals for entering purchase orders, bills, creating invoices, writing checks, and making deposits. After entering the transactions, QuickBooks automatically updates the general ledger.

The general ledger data is used to create a trial balance, which lists all the transactions in the appropriate accounts. From this list, QuickBooks generates financial statements, including the profit and loss statement and the balance sheet. These statements provide a comprehensive overview of the financial status of the business.

When setting up a QuickBooks file, it is essential to establish the accounts that will be used to capture and track all business transactions. This initial setup is crucial for accurate bookkeeping and financial reporting.

QuickBooks stores transactions in the chart of accounts, which includes five main account types: assets, liabilities, equity, income, and expense. Sub-accounts can be created for more detailed categorization. It is important to avoid classifying transactions under miscellaneous or as bank accounts to ensure accurate tax deductions.

The profit and loss report in QuickBooks consists of income minus expenses, resulting in the net income or net profit. Income and expense are part of the main accounts in the chart of accounts and can have sub-accounts for detailed categorization.

The balance sheet report in QuickBooks includes assets, liabilities, and equity, all of which are part of the main accounts in the chart of accounts. This provides a comprehensive overview of the financial position.

Assets, liabilities, and equity are key components of the balance sheet. The balance sheet provides a snapshot of the financial condition at a specific point in time. It shows how the assets are financed through liabilities and equity.

The profit and loss report and the balance sheet work together. The information from the profit and loss report flows through the equity section of the balance sheet. Net profit or loss affects the equity on the balance sheet.

QuickBooks uses the double-entry bookkeeping system. This means that every financial transaction is recorded with at least one debit and one credit. The fundamental accounting equation is assets equals liabilities plus owner's equity.
The accounting equation (assets = liabilities + owner's equity) must remain balanced. Each transaction affects both sides of the equation. Debits must equal credits in every transaction.
In a transaction, assets and expenses increase with a debit, while liabilities, equity, and income increase with a credit. Every transaction must have both a debit and a credit to maintain balance.

For example, when Mark pays a bill of 500, the checking account (asset) is credited, and the liability account is debited. This ensures that the credit of 500 equals the debit of 500, maintaining the balance in the accounting equation.

Let's take a look at more examples. Here we have a worksheet of all the transactions that we've done for the month of January. Every time we do a transaction, it's on one side of the equation and the other side of the equation. If our first investment was of $40,000 into the cash account, we will credit our equity for $40,000. We can also do the same transactions on the same side, however, it must equal the right side of the equation. If we're going to credit cash or take money out of the bank accounts to purchase equipment to put it into our business, technically it is zero on the left side of the equation and zero on the right side of the equation. After we have entered all of our transactions and we look at our ending balances, if we add thirty three thousand five hundred plus eight thousand, that equals forty one thousand five hundred. It should equal the right side of the equation. Our four hundred forty thousand and eleven hundred equals forty one thousand five hundred, so we are in balance.

Let's take a look at the balance sheet in QuickBooks. Total assets equals six hundred thirty five thousand 33 and 93 cents. This number should be equal to our liabilities and owner's equity. If your numbers are not the same, if your assets do not equal your liabilities and equity, then you have posted something incorrectly and you need to go back and try to figure out what was entered incorrectly. It's important to understand what goes on behind the scenes in order to know that your financial statements are up to date and correct. QuickBooks is a double entry bookkeeping system that handles all the debits and credits behind the scenes. Not only will you be able to identify the problems in your bookkeeping records if there are any, but you will also be able to use and understand the meaning of the information.

For example, if you want to know how much money you are bringing into your business, you can look at the income statement. This will show you how much money you have made and how much money you have spent. It's important to understand where your money is coming from and where it is going. This will help you make better decisions for your business and help you to be more successful in the long run.

If you want to know how much liability your company carries, that would be the liability section in your balance sheet. Or how much your business is worth, you will see the equity in your balance sheet. Just remember that the better you understand how the numbers flow on to your reports, the better prepared you will be to make business decisions.

It's great that QuickBooks makes bookkeeping easier for non-accounting users by handling the debits and credits. We have come to the conclusion of our video and I thank you for joining us - introduction to QuickBooks bookkeeping basics.
